text:
A package is useful for a few things:

1. Organizing a large amount of code into a standard structure than can be more easily understood by other developers and users
2. Organizing namespaces (`using Computanigans: AvailablePotentialEnergy`) rather than `include("big_script.jl")` that brings lots of names into scope, and rather than `include("some_module.jl"); using .SomeModule: AvailablePotentialEnergy` which is slightly longer)
3. Being able to install it from the julia registry (`pkg> add Computanigans` rather than having to look up the github address)
4. Automated testing to ensure that computations are correct (doesn’t have to come right away but is useful if you want to publish results or undertake long-term research projects…)
5. Managing dependencies (the package will depend on a particular version of Oceananigans, which has its own dependencies, and the package manager has lots of tools for managing environments and such when dependency restrictions come from multiple sources)
Might be other good reasons? Downsides are not heavy, but you do have to learn the basic incantations that create a package (mostly `pkg> generate Computanigans`)
